awd_titl_txt: BD Spokes: SPOKE: WEST: Accelerating and Catalyzing Reproducibility in Scientific Computation and Data Synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Norms of transparency and knowledge sharing in science encourage new research to build on prior discoveries, leading to rapid innovation and significant societal returns. This project establishes a new activity to help make scientific computation and data science more transparent and accessible. Computation has evolved from tools for assisting scientific research to digital laboratories where fundamental scientific discoveries take place. This is increasingly so for social and ecological sciences, which are combining big data with computational models to better understand the social and earth systems whose complex dynamics underlie many of the grand challenges faced by humanity today. Organized as a Spoke in the National Science Foundation's Big Data Innovation Hub and Spoke network, this project establishes a next generation, online Computational Model Library (CMLX). 

In the CMLX, software code for computational models used in social and ecological sciences is published and freely accessible to the scientific community and general public, and linked with an online database of scientific papers reporting on associated model-based science. In addition to the code library, the CMLX is developing an online repository to archive end-to-end workflows of model-based science, where the entire research process can be followed and reproduced, from data synthesis, to modeling, analysis, and visualization. A regional Working Group - including software developers, data providers, and user communities - will provide advice and expertise, as well as help establish community-wide standards for transparency and accessibility in scientific computation. The CMLX is enabling transparent access to scientific procedures, models, and data that can be used to assess the consequences of alternative scenarios, policies, and assumptions for more sustainable management of complexly coupled human and earth systems.

por.por_cntn:
This project establishes a national center to help make scientific computation and data science more transparent and accessible. Computation has evolved from tools for assisting scientific research into digital laboratories where fundamental scientific discoveries take place. This is increasingly so for social and ecological sciences, which are combining big data with computational models to better understand the social and earth systems whose complex dynamics underlie many of the grand challenges faced by humanity today. 

In this project, the Network for Computational Modeling in Social and Ecological Sciences (CoMSES Net) was organized as a "spoke" of the West Big Data Innovation Hub (https://westbigdatahub.org) in the National Science Foundation's Big Data Innovation Hub and Spoke network. CoMSES Net, is an open community of over 3,000 researchers, educators, and professionals with a common goal of improving the way computational models are developed, shared, used, and re-used for better understanding social and ecological systems. CoMSES.Net develops and maintains the freely accessible CoMSES Science Gateway (https://comses.net) to support discovery and good practices for software citation, digital preservation, reproducibility, and reuse; and the CoMSES Model Library, an open access, digital repository of scientific model code with nearly 1,000 models currently available. CoMSES.Net is governed by an international executive board and ex-officio co-directors (PIs on projects that fund CoMSES Net), under community drafted by-laws (https://www.comses.net/about/by-laws/).

Over the period funded by this award, CoMSES.Net membership nearly doubled, as 1,453 scientists, model developers, and model users joined the network. Over 100,000 users, from nearly every country in the world, visited the CoMSES Science Gateway to make use of its wide array of educational and professional development resources, as well as search, view, and download models from the Model Library. The models in the Library more than doubled during this project, as scientists published 485 new models. Code and documentation were downloaded over 230,000 times from the Model Library during the period funded in this project. 

CoMSES.Net teaches a Winter Modeling School for advanced, hands on training aimed specifically at early career scholars. Computational modeling is only rarely taught in universities, especially for students in fields outside of computer science--even though many will need to use these information technologies. Using digital tools for collaborative, team science--another key emphasis of the Winter Modeling School--is formally taught even more rarely, if at all, in spite of its recognized importance to science of the future. The CoMSES.Net Winter Modeling School fills this gap, teaching over 100 students from 28 countries (including the USA) during this project. 

In this project, CoMSES.Net worked with many other organizations supporting modeling science around the world to establish the Open Modeling Foundation (OMF) (https://openmodelingfoundation.github.io). The OMF is an international alliance of organizations working to create common standards and best practices for modeling science. These standards and practices can enable a next-generation ecosystem of reusable, interoperable models to study complex interactions between people and the environment at multiple scales.

Scientific code is the laboratory of an increasing amount of cutting edge science being performed today, particularly for convergent, interdisciplinary research. Yet an analysis of nearly 8,000 papers on computational modeling carried out by CoMSES.Net shows that these modeling laboratories are inaccessible or lost forever for nearly 90% of the modeling science that has been performed in the past 30 years, and over 80% of the modeling science performed even today (https://catalog.comses.net). For even the most conscientious scientists, there has been a lack of options available for preserving and sharing these computational laboratories to advance science. CoMSES.Net is one of the few organizations that is actively working to provide a national model commons to preserve modeling laboratories today and recover as much as possible of past computational laboratories. CoMSES.Net was founded on the recognition that for modeling science to advance rapidly to meet equally rapidly growing needs in science and society, there must be new ways to disseminate and share computational knowledge. Because traditional journal publications alone are insufficient for this purpose, CoMSES Net has developed a sophisticated online code library and model commons to provide better ways for scientists to make their knowledge available to others. 

In this respect, it is critical to also recognize the importance of cyberinfrastructure with the potential to be a shared resource that broadly benefits scientific innovation and discovery--including online, digital information platforms and networks that support shared databases, data access hubs, research software repositories, and analysis environments. Information technologies are becoming an increasingly important tool for planning and decision making across the public and private sectors. The CoMSES Net BD Spoke is actively working to ensure that all citizens, regardless of their occupation, wealth, or location have equal access to these important tools and products of scientific computation.
